pages:
STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
March 2, 2020
Rick Sanville
Upper Peninsula Family Solutions
369 US 41 East
Negaunee, MI 49866
RE: License #: CB520304693
Investigation #: 2020C0102008
Upper Peninsula Family Solutions
Dear Mr. Sanville:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violation identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective
action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the Modified
Implementation Sustainability and Exit Plan (MISEP) requirements and your contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Claudia Triestram, Area Manager at (616) 552-3662.
01/2015 P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909-8150
www.michigan.gov  (517) 284-9740

Sincerely,
Don Collier, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Suite 11
701 S. Elmwood
Traverse City, MI 49684
(231) 342-5326
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB520304693
Investigation #: 2020C0102008
Complaint Receipt Date: 01/10/2020
Investigation Initiation Date: 01/14/2020
Report Due Date: 03/10/2020
Licensee Name: Upper Peninsula Family Solutions
Licensee Address: 369 US 41 East
Negaunee, MI 49866
Licensee Telephone #: (906) 228-2267
Administrator: Rick Sanville
Licensee Designee: Tracey Compton, Designee
Name of Facility: Upper Peninsula Family Solutions
Facility Address: 369 US 41 East
Negaunee, MI 49866
Facility Telephone #: (906) 273-1095
Original Issuance Date: 11/19/2009
License Status: REGULAR
Effective Date: 05/19/2018
Expiration Date: 05/18/2020
Capacity: Unknown
Program Type: CHILD PLACING AGENCY, PRIVATE

II. ALLEGATION(S)
Violation
Established?
The agency has failed to make a timely assessment of a relative No
for placement.
Additional Findings Yes
III. METHODOLOGY
01/10/2020 Special Investigation Intake
2020C0102008
01/14/2020 Special Investigation Initiated - Face to Face
Met with Supervisor 2 and 3, Director 4, and Licensing Worker 5
02/24/2020 Contact - Telephone call made
Called Foster Care Worker 1, Supervisor 3, email from Supervisor
3, reviewed MiSACWIS records
02/24/2020 Contact - Telephone call received
Interviewed Licensing Worker 5
02/25/2020 Contact - Telephone call received
Interviewed Relative A
02/24/2020 Exit Conference
Special Investigation results given to Supervisor 3
ALLEGATION:
The agency has failed to make a timely assessment of a relative for placement.
Foster Care Worker 1 does not return telephone calls to Relative A.
Licensing Worker 5 canceled appointments on 12/23/2019 and 01/02/2020
INVESTIGATION:
Foster Child B and Foster Child C were placed in foster care with Foster Parent G
from 08/20/2018 to 08/26/2019. Foster Child B and Foster Child C were then placed

with Parent D and Parent E from 08/26/2019 to 12/09/2019. The two children were
then removed on 12/09/2019 and placed with Foster parent F.
The MiSACWIS (Michigan Statewide Automated Child Welfare Information System)
entry for a social work contact on 12/10/2019 read as follows (names coded):
Removal hearing took place, however, (Parent E) had not attended the hearing
even though she was provided notice of the hearing the night prior. (Parent E)
completed a random drug screen with (Court Worker 6) that morning which
tested positive. (Parent E) then left the courthouse and didn't stay for the removal
hearing. (Parent D) told the court that he thought that he caught his relapse early
enough and he greatly downplayed his issues. Judge ordered visitations to
continue to take place as long as supervised. Parenting time is not contingent
upon a clean drug screen. Prior to the removal hearing, (Relative A) and (Parent
D) spoke to this worker. (Relative A) now told this worker that he had spoken to
his work and the girls’ daycare and both places are able to work with him in order
for him to be able to take the girls. Worker expressed to (Relative A) that she
had concerns about him being able to care for the girls as this weekend he had
said that he couldn't care for them. (Relative A) then told worker that he could
care for the girls and then (Relative A) asked if (Parent E) would be able to help
him. This worker stated that "no" (Parent E) couldn't help him with the girls as
she has an open case and her parenting time is supervised and if he were to
take the girls he would have to meet all of their needs. (Relative A) looked
disappointment that (Parent E) wouldn't be able to help him but then said that he
would still like his home to be looked at. Worker told him that a licensing worker
would be in contact with him.
Foster Care Worker 1 was contacted by telephone on 02/24/2020. She said that she
returns calls from Relative A “all the time”. She said that there are some days with
multiple messages from Relative A. Foster Care Worker 1 said that Relative A told her
he could not take Foster Child B and Foster Child C when he was asked at the time of
the second removal from the parents home. Foster Care Worker 1 said that Relative A
had to check with his work and arrange daycare for the girls. Foster Care Worker 1 said
that now there are concerns with placing Foster Child B and Foster Child C with him
because he is growing marijuana in his home and Relative A had a Wisconsin criminal
conviction involving growing marijuana that he did not disclose to the agency.
I received that following email from Supervisor 3 written by Licensing Worker 5 on
02/24/2020:
I was asked to complete the 3130A for (Relative A) the week of December 9th. I
called and scheduled an initial meeting with him for Tuesday, December 17th,
however was it was cancelled as I was out sick on that day. I was on vacation
the week of Christmas, so contacted him when I got back after New Year’s and
rescheduled for January 6th, which was when we met for the first time. During
that visit there were licensing/safety concerns that Relative A needed to fix, so he

was asked to contact me when they were done for me to come back to the
house. I had a death in my family that week and ended up scheduling with him
for January 20th. At that visit, the safety concerns/licensing rules were still not
completed, so I scheduled to come back the following week. I completed another
home visit on January 27th, at which time the changes had still not been made to
the home, and I provided (Relative A) with the information regarding the
recommendation for denial. He was told at that time that he could contact me
again to be reassessed, should he decide to make the necessary safety changes
to his home. I received a phone call from (Relative A) on February 6th, and he
asked me to come back out to assess his home. However, during the discussion
with him it became clear that he had not made any changes to his home at this
point and that his son (who is the father to the granddaughters he is seeking
placement of) moved into his home following his release from jail. (Relative A)
was notified that the changes to the home needed to be done, and his son
needed to have an alternative living arrangement before I came back for another
assessment. I have not heard from him since that time.
Foster Care Worker 1 was interviewed for a second time by telephone on 02/24/2020.
She that children were at either a neighbor or family of Parent E, she could not
remember which one, and then moved to the maternal grandmother. The grandmother
said she could not care for the children, according to Foster Care Worker 1 and the
children were placed in foster care by Foster Care Worker 1. She said that after three
days the children were moved to another foster home, Foster parent G. Foster Care
Worker 1 said that at the time of removal Relative A was unable to take placement of
Foster Child B and Foster Child C in August 2018. As stated above the children where
return to Parent D who was no longer with Parent E. Foster Care Worker 1 said there
were no other relatives who showed interest in the placement of these children. Foster
Care Worker 1 said the case was originally the case of Foster Care Worker 9. Foster
Care Worker 1 said that Foster Care Worker 9 started evaluations of Relative A. Foster
Care Worker 9 left the agency.
In MiSACWIS records dated 08/20/2018 Relative A declined placement of Foster Child
B and Foster Child C due to health. The DHS-987 Relative Documentation was
completed by Dickinson County DHHS. Relative A returned a DHS-990, Relative
Response checking the boxes by both temporary and permanent placement of Foster
Child B and Foster Child C.
Licensing Worker 5 wrote the following narrative which was emailed to me by
Supervisor 3 on 02/14/2020. Licensing Worker 5 wrote in her narrative that there were
issues with Relative A becoming approved for Foster Child B and Foster Child C. She
wrote that there were two grow rooms in the house for growing marijuana and she had
counted 13 plants and the law allows 12. She asked Relative A for a safety plan when
he was under the influence of marijuana and he was not cooperative with developing a
safety plan. Licensing Worker 5 wrote that there was a problem with the upstairs
bedroom that Relative A proposed that Foster Child B and Foster Child C were to sleep
in. She wrote that the stairway was very narrow, and the bedroom door did not latch.

There was also a very low ceiling above the stairway. Relative A was not truthful
regarding a felony marijuana conviction in Wisconsin in 1998. Licensing Worker 5 also
wrote the Relative A’s home smelled of tobacco and marijuana smoke. Licensing
Worker 5 wrote that she felt that Relative A would not protect the children from their
biological parents.
Relative A called me back on 02/25/2020. We talked for a short time and I attempted to
arrange a call back time and Relative A said he would call back on 02/26/2020. Relative
A said he would call back and did not want me to call him. There was no substance to
the conversation with Relative A. As of 03/01/2020 I have not heard back from Relative
A.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12404 Placement.
(4) An agency shall consider all of the following factors in
selecting an appropriate placement for a child:
(e) The continuity of relationships, including relationships
with parents, siblings, relatives, foster parents, previous foster
parents, and other persons significant to the child.
ANALYSIS: Upper Peninsula Family Solutions considered Relative A for
placement of Foster Child A and Foster Child B. They had
concerns about the safety of the proposed bedroom
arrangement, growing marijuana, and the smoking of tobacco
and marijuana.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
INVESTIGATION:
In reviewing the records on this case in MiSACWIS, the contact for 12/102019 was
entered on 02/17/2020 into MiSACWIS.
APPLICABLE RULE
FOM 722-06H TIMELY ENTRY OF CASE CONTACTS
Page 18
All case contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS, including
attempted contacts and missed appointments. The case
contact narrative should consist of a brief summary of the

contact. Significant information obtained during the contact
must be summarized in the appropriate section of the case
service plan.
The caseworker must enter the required face-to-face contacts
listed below in MISACWIS within five business days of the
contact. This includes attempted and missed face-to-face
contacts.
 Any face-to-face contact with children, parents, or
caregivers made by any of the following:
Foster care caseworker/supervisor.
CPS caseworker/supervisor.
Adoption caseworker/supervisor.
Permanency resource monitors.
Education planners.
Michigan Youth Opportunities Initiative
coordinators.
 Parent/child face-to-face contacts.
 Sibling face-to-face contacts.
All other case contacts must be entered prior to the report
period end date on the applicable case service plan.
ANALYSIS: The contact with Parent D on 12/10/2019 was not entered in
MISACWIS until 02/17/2020, which was not within five business
days of the contact.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
INVESTIGATION:
Relative A expressed an interest in the placement on form DHS 990, signed and
date stamped at the Dickinson County DHHS office on 08/22/2018. Upper Peninsula
Family Solutions received the foster care case on 08/17/2018. The required
MDHHS-5770 Relative Placement Safety Screen form is not in MiSACWIS
Foster Care Worker 1 said she was involved in the original placement of Foster
Child B and Foster Child C even though she was not assigned the case. Foster Care
Worker 9 should have completed a MDHHS-5770 Relative Placement Safety Screen
form. The DHS-990 form was dated 08/22/2018 and loaded into MiSACWIS on
08/23/2018.

APPLICABLE RULE
FOM 722-03B RELATIVE ENGAGMENT AND PLACEMENT
Page 5
Subsequent or Planned Placements
Caseworkers must complete a Relative Placement Safety -
Screen for all adult relatives who express an interest in
placement, within five business days of the relative's written
request for placement consideration.
If the relative meets the requirements on the Relative Placement
Safety Screen, then he/she must be fully assessed on the
Relative Placement Home Study prior to placement; see
Relative Placement Home Study in this item, for timeframes for
completion.
ANALYSIS: MDHHS-5770 Relative Placement Safety Screen form was not
completed within 5 days of Relative A’s expression of interest.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon the receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, I recommend no change to
the licensing status of this public child placing agency.
03/01/2020
________________________________________
Don Collier Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
March 2, 2020
________________________________________
Claudia Triestram Date
Area Manager

sir_summary.summary: The investigation concerned allegations that the agency failed to timely assess a relative for placement of children, which was not substantiated. However, the investigation revealed two other violations: a failure to document a case contact in the state system within the required five business days, and a failure to complete a required Relative Placement Safety Screen within five business days of the relative's expressed interest. The agency bears responsibility for these administrative and procedural failures.

sir_violation_level.justification: The substantiated violations are: 1) A case contact was not entered into the MiSACWIS system within five business days, and 2) A required Relative Placement Safety Screen form was not completed within five business days of a relative's interest. Both are administrative paperwork/documentation errors, fitting the 'low' category for 'Administrative or paperwork issues: missing signatures on required forms, minor documentation errors, late submission of a report.'
